qas.question: What kind of cell identifies pathogens when the antibodies on its surface complex with a specific foreign antigen?
What is the process by which the antigen/antibody complex is processed in to peptides?
What does the matching helper T cell release when it binds with the MHC:antigen complex of the B cell?

plausible_answers.text: antibodies on its surface bind to a specific foreign antigen

qas.question: When does a T cell identify pathogens?
What attracts a matching helper B cell?
When do antibodies not circulate in?

context: <a0_2>A <a0_0><a0_1>B<a0_1/> cell<a0_2/><a0_0/> identifies pathogens when <b3_0>antibodies on its surface bind to a specific foreign antigen<b3_0/>. This <b4_0>antigen/antibody complex<b4_0/> is taken up by the B cell and processed by <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>proteolysis<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> into peptides. The B cell then displays these antigenic peptides on its surface MHC class II molecules. This <b5_0>combination of MHC and antigen<b5_0/> attracts a matching helper T cell, which releases <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>lymphokines<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> and activates the B cell. As the activated B cell then begins to divide, its offspring (plasma cells) secrete millions of copies of the antibody that recognizes this antigen. These antibodies circulate in <b6_0>blood plasma<b6_0/> and lymph, bind to pathogens expressing the antigen and mark them for destruction by complement activation or for uptake and destruction by phagocytes. Antibodies can also neutralize <b7_0>challenges<b7_0/> directly, by binding to bacterial toxins or by interfering with the receptors that viruses and bacteria use to infect cells.
